conclusion: The ball A is positioned above the yellow block group and falls freely under gravity.

When A falls, it impacts one of the yellow blocks.

Assuming A hits the right yellow block first, it would transfer some energy to the block.
After hitting the yellow block, A will likely be deflected horizontally due to the collision.
The exact deflection direction depends on the angle and elasticity of the collision.
After the collision, A continues to move until it comes to rest.
A might roll or bounce slightly away due to any residual energy.
The final resting position will be close to the point of impact but slightly deflected.
The yellow blocks may shift slightly due to the impact, depending on how much energy is transferred.
A collides with the yellow blocks.
A is likely to rest near the yellow blocks, slightly deflected to the right or left depending on the collision's specifics.
This analysis assumes a typical elastic collision with no significant external forces apart from gravity.
